contentrichtext.text: {{Expand Greek|date=December 2008|Νίκος Ξυλούρης}} {{Infobox musical artist |name = Nikos Xylouris<br />{{lang|el|Νίκος Ξυλούρης}} |image = NikosXilouris.jpg |caption = |image_size = 150 |background = solo_singer |birth_name = |alias = |birth_date = {{birth date|1936|7|7}} |origin = [[Anogeia]], [[Crete]], [[Greece]] |death_date = {{death date and age|1980|2|8|1936|7|17}} |instrument = |genre = |occupation = [[Composer]], [[singer]] |years_active = |label = |associated_acts = |website = |notable_instruments = [[Lyra (Cretan)]] }} {{for|the Greek swimmer (born in 1982)|Nikos Xylouris (swimmer)}} '''Nikos Xylouris''' ({{lang-el|Νίκος Ξυλούρης}}; 7 July 1936 – 8 February 1980), nicknamed Psaronikos ({{lang-el|Ψαρονίκος}}, 'Gray-haired Nick'), was a [[Greece|Greek]] composer and singer from the village of [[Anogeia]] in [[Crete]] and also the older brother of two other great musicians of [[Cretan music]], Antonis Xylouris or [[Psarantonis]] ({{lang-el|Ψαραντώνης}}) and Yiannis Xylouris or (Psaroyiannis) ({{lang-el|Ψαρογιάννης}}). He was part of the movement that brought down the [[Greek military junta of 1967-1974|Greek military Junta]] of 1967{{Citation needed|date=March 2009}}. His songs and music captured and described the [[Greeks|Greek]] psyche and demeanor, gaining himself the title ''the [[archangel]] of Crete''. Psaronikos is a nickname as it is customary for people in Anogeia to have. His grandfather was Psarantonis. His grandfather kept company with a group of 5-6 men who stole from the Turks. As he was the fastest runner in the group, when they met with Turks he was running very fast and he could catch all of them as if they were fish. So, first he was given the name Fishturk (Greek: 'Ψαρότουρκος') and then the nickname Psarantonis. That is how all family male members after him were nicknamed Psaronikos, Psarogiorgis, Psarantonis etc. ( this is explained by Psarantonis, Nikos Xylouris' brother in an interview presented on his homepage). He acquired his first [[Lyra (Cretan)|lyra]] at the age of twelve and displayed potential to play local folk music. Xylouris was 17 years of age when he started performances at ''Kastro'' folk music-restaurant in Heraklion. A turning point in Nikos Xylouris' career occurred with a recording in 1958. He first performed outside [[Greece]] in 1966 and won the first prize in the San Remo folk music festival. In 1967 he established the first Cretan Music Hall, ''Erotokritos'', in [[Heraklion]]. The recording of ''Anyfantou'' in 1969 was a big success. Xylouris soon started performances in [[Athens]], which became his new permanent residence, at the ''Konaki'' folk music hall. During the early 1970s, Xylouris' voice becomes identified not only with Cretan music but also with the new kind of artistic popular music that emerged as well-known composers such as [[Giannis Markopoulos]], [[Stavros Xarhakos]], [[Christodoulos Halaris]] and [[Christos Leontis]] wrote music on the verses of famous Greek poets among which stand out [[Nikos Gatsos]], [[Yannis Ritsos]], [[Giorgos Seferis]], [[Kostas Varnalis]] and [[Dionysios Solomos]]. In 1971, Xylouris is awarded by the Academy Charles Cross of [[France]] for his performance in the Cretan Rizitika songs album with G. Markopoulos. He died in 1980 from a [[brain tumor]], and is buried in the [[First Cemetery of Athens]]. ==See also== * [[Music of Crete]] ==External links== * http://cretanhistory.tripod.com/biograf/xiloyris.htm * [http://www.iovhellas.gr/english/article.php?date=2006-02-25%2020:24:00 Musical, political and social portrait of Nikos Xylouris] * [http://www.youtube.com/results?search_query=Nikos+%28Xilouris+OR+Xylouris+OR+Ksilouris%29&search_sort=video_view_count Nikos Xilouris on YouTube] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Xylouris, Nikos | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Greek composer-singer | DATE OF BIRTH = 7 July 1936 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 8 February 1980 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Xylouris, Nikos}} [[Category:Cretan musicians]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:Greek songwriters]] [[Category:Singers from Crete]] [[Category:Deaths from brain tumor]] [[Category:Burials in Athens]]
